awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  An Oleophilic Hydrophobic Magnetic (OHM) Sponge for Environmental Remediation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this STTR Phase I project is to develop an environmental remediation platform for oil spills and related contaminants in water bodies.  Oil spills and associated heavy metals/toxins have significant economic, social, and environmental adverse impacts. The current state-of-the-art approaches are expensive, pose dangers to marine life, and/or generate physical waste. This project introduces a widely deployable sponge technology that attracts oil and resists water.  It can selectively remove and recover oil from an oil/water mixture and is re-usable. The materials/methods in the proposed project are cost-effective, scalable, and ecologically friendly. 

The intellectual merit of the proposed project is to advance a technology leveraging the interfacial tension at an oil-water interface.  This project develops a nanotechnology-based simple and scalable sponge that can selectively sequester oil molecules and metal toxins from an oil-water interface. The proposed system coats commercially available sponges with a nanocomposite material.  Activities include optimization of key factors affecting interactions between oil and metal toxins with nanocomposites coated on sponge pores and tailoring both the length-scale and chemical architecture for remediation applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

Oil spills have huge and immediate economic, and environmental adverse impacts. The current state-of-the-art approaches to clean oil spills are expensive, increase carbon footprint, pose danger to marine life, and generate a lot of physical waste. NSF Phase I STTR project demonstrated a novel oil spill remediation solution in the form of a sponge, that is more efficient, economic, and eco-friendly than the current approaches. Named as OHM sponge, it can be used to remove and recover oil from oil contaminated water. OHM sponge can be made by coating thin layer of OHM nanocomposite on any commercially available sponge, such as polyurethane. It can selectively absorb oil over 25-30 times its own weight, be squeezed out, and be reused dozens of times. The recovery of oil and reusability of the sponge significantly improves the oil clean-up efficiency and reduces the oil clean-up cost. The materials/methods for OHM sponge are cost-effective, scalable, and eco-friendly. The NSF STTR Phase I steps were addressed towards:

(i)              Enhancing the oil absorption efficiency of OHM sponge by optimizing multiple development factors such as coating composition, thickness, and formulation.

(ii)            Utilize complementary surface chemistry to achieve strong binding of OHM nanocomposite coating with the sponge substrate.

(iii)          Expanding the application of OHM sponge to produced water treatment and heavy metal removal. For testing and comparing purposes, water with heavy metal and oil concentrations close to that found in the real-world scenarios were used.

 

Intellectual Merit

This project aimed to improve the key features of OHM Sponge by conducting series of tests such as coating formulation, introducing surface functionality to overcome the challenges to achieve maximum oil absorption efficiency of OHM Sponge. Following provides overview on this:

The development of novel OHM sponge is achieved by coating commercially available sponges (such as polyurethane) with a specially designed OHM (Oleophilic Hydrophobic and Multifunctional) nanocomposite material and thus named as ?OHM sponge?. This project helped identifying factors like coating formulation, composition, and thickness that led to OHM sponge's highest oil adsorption behavior. To improve its life cycle, OHM nanocomposite coating was made more stable by adding a chemical treatment stage during the coating step. This helped create a strong bond between the coating and sponge surface at same time without any compromise on the performance. Expanding the application beyond oil spill clean-up, a different formulation of OHM sponge, named as OHM media, was developed. While OHM sponge is useful in cases where oil is floating on the water, the OHM media can be used where oil is mixed throughout in water (oil/water emulsion). This is particularly useful for industrial wastewater/produced water treatment. With further modification in the OHM nanocomposite formulation, OHM media was advanced to remove other pollutants like heavy/toxic metals. OHM media performed superior against commercially available filtration media (such as granulated activated carbon or walnut shell) when tested for heavy metal removal.

 

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of this project extend beyond immediate research outcomes, encompassing advancements in knowledge, economic growth, education, and public engagement, all working towards benefiting society at large.

Public knowledge

OHM products received extensive media coverage through articles in NSF, research magazines/blogs, and interviews. Due to this reach, a local food facility approached MFNS Tech to address the issue of high FOG (Fats, Oils, and Grease) levels in their wastewater. As a result of this discussion, we initiated one of our pilot studies using OHM Media. Initially, samples were collected from the food facility and tested at our laboratory. The test results yielded positive outcomes, prompting us to proceed with on-site testing of the wastewater. Currently, the analysis of these samples is still ongoing, and we are in the process of planning the next steps accordingly.

Education and engagement

Other positive outcomes of the media coverage were the feedback that we received from school students and teachers. As a result, we decided to develop an OHM sponge demo kit which included OHM sponge sample pieces, how-to-use manual, and other accessories. This demo kit was sent to interested students where they used it for instances like project demonstrations, science fair projects. The students were able to have a hands-on experience of the product and learn more about oil spills and their impact on the environment.

Outreach

The subaward PI of this project was also given an opportunity to deliver a TEDx Talk on oil spills and the use of OHM sponge to clean up. The talk was well-received by audience and helped to raise awareness of the issue of oil spills and potential of OHM sponge to help clean them up. The TEDx Talk was also helpful for us to scale up our outreach activities. We were able to reach a broader audience with our message about the importance of environmental protection and the potential of OHM products to help protect the environment.
